channel.title: Teaching on Justin Pearson
channel.description: Recent content in Teaching on Justin Pearson

item.title: Artificial Intelligence.
item.description:
• Studium Page
  • Official Syllabus

This course is co-taught with Maria Andreina Francisco Rodriguez who is the main teacher. The course covers various aspects of AI that are not concerned with machine learning including heuristic search, planning and scheduling, statistical learning, Bayesian networks, AI in computer games.

item.title: Category Theory for Programmers.
item.description:
PhD reading course going through Bartosz Milewski's book on Category theory. Mostly organised by Nikolaus Huber.

Information can be found on:

  • Information

Some Additional Resources.

  • A good collection of Links on category theory.

  • Tom Leinster's excellent book is available free online.

  • Some notes that might be useful. If you don't read the notes, then a look at the references, which has pointers to a lot of good resources.

  • Emily Riehl's Book Category Theory in Context contains lots of examples of common constructions in category theory. Some of the examples might require some background in algebra. You can also buy the book quite cheaply from Dover

item.title: Algorithms and Data Structures II
item.description:
Useful links:

  • Slides and Assigments.
  • Official Syllabus

This is a second course in algorithms that topics such as

  • solving recursive equations that describe the algorithm's complexity
  • dynamic programming
  • greedy algorithms
  • graph algorithms: minimum spanning trees, shortest paths
  • string matching
  • union find.

item.title: Introduction to Machine Learning
item.description:
Useful links:

  • Slides and Assigments
  • Official Syllabus

This is a first course in machine learning. The course covers basic supervised and unsupervised methods (for example, regression, classification, decision trees, clustering), use of established tools for machine learning, application of the methods to real data, and practical aspects such as dimensionality reduction and cross validation. The course also introduces ethical aspects of bias in machine learning.
